issues.title: Cleanup for "additional information" in media type registration
issues.author: alvestrand
issues.body:
From Paul Libbrecht:

Just a reminder: if we update RFC 6838 then it would be cool to:

*    remove “Macintosh file type code(s)” (which doesn’t exist anymore since MacOSX)
*    add “Windows clipboard flavour” and “macOS Universal Type Identifier” among the additional information fields.

comments.author: polx
alvestrand
comments.body:
The RFC Editors page at https://www.rfc-editor.org/info/rfc6838 seems to not list one. The RFC predates the universal presence of XML formats.

There's an XML format on the I-D page for the last-before-publication I-D: https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/draft-ietf-appsawg-media-type-regs/14/

I think either Tony Hansen or John Klensin might have one too.

comments.author: polx
comments.body:
OK. So here would be a patch and the resulting XML compared to [the last-before-publication I-D](https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/draft-ietf-appsawg-media-type-regs/14/):

In substance:
- replace the suggestion to the MacOS file type by the suggestions for macOS UTIs and Windows clipboard flavor names
- replace the literature entry of MacOS file type (which was 21 y old and whose URL is no longer available, an [archive fetch](https://web.archive.org/web/20080517021842/http://www.info.apple.com/kbnum/n55381) exists still) by an explanation of the macOS UTIs and windows clipboard flavors.

Is this enough for an inclusion? 
Should this be more text-oriented to be included in a new RFC?
Or should the RFC 6838 be made into a newer document, maybe together with the mediaman release?

thanks in advance.
Paul

* [add-clipboard-flavor-names.patch](https://github.com/ietf-wg-mediaman/procedures/files/14473152/add-clipboard-flavor-names.patch)
* The resulting XML file is called `.txt` since GitHub considereds XML unsupported (LOL):  [draft-ietf-appsawg-media-type-regs-14.xml.txt](https://github.com/ietf-wg-mediaman/procedures/files/14473159/draft-ietf-appsawg-media-type-regs-14.xml.txt)

comments.author: polx
comments.body: Following the existing pull-requests, I added a pull-request against the current markdown source in the git repo to address the same changes.

comments.author: alvestrand
comments.body: Fixed by #17 - new issues may be raised for the topics mentioned in the PR.

comments.author: polx
comments.body:
Thank you very much.

> Discussion in Bangkok: Perfectly reasonable to do, worry about whether backfill can be done for older types.

The first step would be to take the official specs of the vendors and back-fill with the content of these.  I am happy to hear about process suggestions.

issues.title: Grandfathering requirements should apply to all unregistered media-types
issues.author: CxRes
issues.body:
I find that the text in paragraph 2 of Appendix A is only targeting unfaceted subtypes that should be registered as faceted. There are unregistered or improperly registered unfaceted subtypes that might need to re-registered as unfaceted. Such as media-types mentioned in https://github.com/ietf-wg-mediaman/procedures/issues/6.

This text should therefore RECOMMEND that in all cases where the media-types are unregistered, missing a registration template or have unstructured templates, they should be re-registered if possible.

comments.author: mnot
comments.body:
I suspect the community format process might subsume the grandfathering text, as well as this under 'Standards Tree':

> or in rare cases when registering a grandfathered (see {{grandfather}}) and/or otherwise incomplete registration is in the interest of the Internet community.

comments.author: mnot
comments.body: See also #33.

comments.author: CxRes
comments.body:
Am I correct in presuming this is the text under 4.1.1.1? Unfortunately, even beyond the list of media-types I mentioned in https://github.com/ietf-wg-mediaman/procedures/issues/6, I have been uncovering more registrations that are not proper templates, but say, email dumps. 

Ideally, I feel the text (not necessarily in that section but somewhere in the document) of broader scope might be needed to allow for all missing/incorrect registrations, as and when discovered, to be fixed (unless you plan to subsume all such cases under "community formats"), which a more general grandfathering text could have served.

comments.author: mnot
comments.body:
So I don't think this is really about grandfathering; it's about how to maintain the registry contents.

One option would be to enable the designated expert(s) to act as custodians of the registry and make improvements along the lines you're suggesting, with appropriate transparency and community consultation. That seems to have worked well in other registries, and also seems to be the model IANA is using (based upon the e-mails you linked in that other issue).

Some spec text about the expert role spelling this out would help.

The other option would be to require an RFC to update these entries. That's heavier weight, but might be required in some cases where the expert didn't feel that they had the authority to make a change.

comments.author: CxRes
comments.body:
I recognize the scope creep since I opened the original issue. Having an opinion about the options you present goes well beyond my pay grade. But if you do go the "heavy weight" route (and I realize this screams scope creep), I have two unrelated request:
1. Consider tracking the history of entries, not every change, but where a spec has been updated or obsoleted. This came up with my conversations with Amanda in Bangkok.
2. Consider mandating a structured format, say YAML, that at a first instance can be machine checked. I gather that Roy Fielding (from his old blog) has been upset about this for the longest time.

comments.author: mnot
comments.body:
For your (1), I think that's a matter of IANA-wide tooling/policy, not something that we want to do per-registry.

For your (2), I suspect that's too high a bar -- the purpose of the registry is to assure that it reflects reality, and anything that is a barrier to entry hurts that.

comments.author: alvestrand
comments.body: No change needed (but see new issue on the term "grandfather").

issues.title: can "Person for further info" be an IETF WG / mailing list?
issues.author: rohanmahy
issues.body:
Some IETF specs (ex: [RC9594](https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc9594.html) use an IETF WG name and mailing list for the Person and Email, but most do not (I saw one that referred IANA to the Editor's Addresses). I would like this document to either tell WGs explicitly "DO THAT" or "DON'T DO THAT" please.

WGs come and go and hopefully live shorter lives than people, but IETF mailing lists can last a pretty long time.

comments.author: alvestrand
comments.body:
Personally, I'm skeptical of MLs as change controllers.
I believe the IESG (or successor bodies) will live longer than most WGs.
Mailing lists are frequently closed when the WG is gone and the maintainer gets tired of dealing with the spam.
Also, mailing lists have no built-in decision procedure - how can you tell if a mailing list with 100+ mostly silent members agree on something?

comments.author: martinthomson
comments.body:
This isn't about change controllers.  There are three relevant fields in the template:

*   Person and email address to contact for further information:
*   Author:  
*   Change controller: 

Recent registrations that I've created use "IETF" for the last and the document authors for the first two.  Rohan is interested in whether the WG mailing list is a better place to point people for the first (I think).  I'd also ask about the second for WG products.

comments.author: rohanmahy
comments.body:
Yes, as Martin said I am referring to the first "Person & email address to
contact for further information:"
thanks,
-rohan

> the template:

comments.author: alvestrand
comments.body: OK, changed the title. In that case, I think an IETF (or other org's) mailing list makes sense; it would be the change controller's responsibility to update the field when a mailing list shuts down.

comments.author: rohanmahy
comments.body:
@mnot as the author do you want to weigh in on this? If you are amenable, I'll send you a short PR. Maybe instead of "Person and email address to contact for further information", it would be clearer: "Contact name and email address for further information". Then the text could explain that Contact name is an IETF/IRTF mailing list if the work is a product of the IETF, or the name/email of a human person otherwise?

And you might as well give your views about the "Author" field as well.

comments.author: mnot
comments.body: I think it's reasonable, but keeping it up to date requires action, and it's often not clear who the action holder is. Somewhat related, I'd like to do some work on clarifying what the responsibilities and powers of a designated expert are.

comments.author: alvestrand
comments.body:
Discussion in Bangkok:
WGs don't last forever, so if we accept that, we need a procedure to update the pointer when they are defunct.
(The same applies to people, but on a longer timescale)
Should we have a fallback pointer? A procedure to get the fallback, depending on change controller?
Fallback pointer may be change controller pointer.
Resolution: Continue discussion in issue.

comments.author: alvestrand
comments.body:
Formally, I think the change controller needs to be responsible for updating the "Person to contact for further info".
I don't like encumbering the DE with too much proactive responsibility - we might ask IANABIS whether they should maintain a database of contact addresses and take the responsibility of flushing out contacts that don't work any more.

comments.author: polx
comments.body:
Assuming the media-types mailing-list is still alive, isn't the procedure used in the media-type declaration (but with a different template) to post an actualization of the contact-addresses at the media-types mailing-list then handling by directors the right method?

The same "authority inspection" worries are concerned here, or? And making it transparent is publicly important for sure.

comments.author: alvestrand
comments.body: This (update procedure) seems to be a more generic question, pertaining to section 6.1 "change procedures". I filed #21 to track that question.

comments.author: mnot
comments.body:
I'm not convinced that a fallback pointer will be any more reliable, and it adds complexity to the procedure and the registry. Also, all existing entries won't have a fallback, limiting the utility of this approach for some time and necessitating a fallback procedure for the absence of a fallback. 

I'd suggest that either: 

1. The expert be given explicit power to chase up unresponsive contacts and update using reasonable measures, with a fallback to the IESG if there's a dispute of their decision.
2. We close this issue without action; it's working well enough.

comments.author: mnot
comments.body:
Note also that the change section already has:

> The IESG may reassign responsibility for a media type. The most common case of this will be to enable changes to be made to types where the author of the registration has died, fallen out of contact, or is otherwise unable to make changes that are important to the community.

comments.author: mnot
comments.body:
Regarding the _original_ issue here, the standards tree section already says:

> The change controller of a media type registered in the standards tree is assumed to be the standards-related organization itself.

We could refine that with something like:

> In the case of IETF standards, the change controller is normally the IESG.

comments.author: polx
comments.body: I am missing the transparency of the operation when the IESG or the experts change reassign. It is probably in some by-laws of the IESG but including that at least the conclusion of a reassignment is visible on the ietf-types mailing-list would help trust, I think. One could adapt the current sentence for this, I think.

comments.author: mnot
comments.body:
Experts are listed in the registry, e.g., https://www.iana.org/assignments/media-types/media-types.xhtml

If we want to have norms/rules for when/how they're announced, I think that should be done in IANABIS, not as a one-off here.

comments.author: polx
comments.body: I am not making in question the list of experts. I proposing adjust the sentence so that a reassignment of responsibility for a media-type is an action that is transparently relayed to some public place such as the mailing-list.

comments.author: mnot
comments.body: I understand. I stand by my comment.

issues.title: What's the correct appeals procedure for DE decisions?
issues.author: alvestrand
issues.body:
From Murray Kucherawy (mailing list Nov 8):

RFC 6838 Section 5.3 creates an appeal process by referencing RFC 2026 Section 6.5.4 and saying that appeals go to the IESG.  That specific part of RFC 2026 suggest the appeal process being established appears to me to boil down to:

* the appeal goes to the IESG, and there's no escalation available past that
* the appeal must provide adequate detail
* the appeal must be filed within two months of the DE's decision
* the IESG has discretion to process the appeal however it wants
* the IESG has to complete its review and deliver its decision in a reasonable amount of time

...or at least that's how I read it.  Maybe I'm being too pedantic but I also note that RFC 2026 Section 6.5.4 is subordinate to Section 6.5, which says that it (and its subsections) apply to decisions that are made as part of the standards process using consensus development, and decisions of a DE do not meet that definition.  It doesn't look to me like 6.5.4 was meant to be referenced or incorporated in this way.

I suggest this is something the WG should review and decide whether it wants to keep this as-is or perhaps say something more explicit and crisp.

comments.author: alvestrand
comments.body:
Notes:
- So far we have no appeals (AFAIK), so we don't know if the process works.
- I believe the choice to point to 6.5.4 directly was deliberately done as "we are reusing the appeals process for a different purpose than what it was originally written for"
- 6.5.4 doesn't specify the appeals chain; I believe the idea was that the response to an appeal under 6.5.4 would be an IESG action, which could then be appealed using the appeals chain in 6.5.2.

comments.author: alvestrand
comments.body: This may be an IANABIS problem.

comments.author: mnot
comments.body: Given that we haven't had any appeals yet and this appears to be workable at least on the face of it, close with no action?

comments.author: aamelnikov
comments.body: My vague recollection is that the intent was to appeal to ART (well, Apps) ADs first, then to IESG, etc. This is probably slightly better than going to full IESG.

comments.author: alvestrand
comments.body: Close with no action; IANABIS may want to consider general rules for appeals of DE decisions, including possible insertion of the relevant AD in the chain.

issues.title: If the intention is to discourage oid/nnnnn, this text could be clearer.
issues.author: mnot
issues.body:
If the intention is to discourage oid/nnnnn, this text could be clearer.

For example: Do not attempt to register top levels wheihc are pointers ....

_Originally posted by @OR13 in https://github.com/ietf-wg-mediaman/6838bis/pull/12#discussion_r1941490850_

comments.author: alvestrand
comments.body:
The "negative criteria" section was added after a discussion on the list where someone suggested a top-level type that would register by implication some huge number of other entities (I think it was, among other things, going to have a separate media type for integers).

We concluded that such a thing would be a Bad Idea, and tried to find some way of incorporating that into the RFC. The "negative criteria" were the result.

We could reformulate it in such a way that either the intro says "the registration process SHOULD/MUST reject attempts to register top level types that satisfies the following criteria", or that each criterion starts off with "You SHOULD NOT attempt to register ....."

I think choosing between these forms is editor's privillege.

comments.author: mnot
comments.body: See also #25.

issues.title: Update Media Type registry to clearer indicate which media types do have RTP payload formats
issues.author: gloinul
issues.body:
With the approval and imminent publication of https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/draft-ietf-avtcore-rtp-payload-registry/ there no longer separate registry for which media types are RTP payload formats. Although if going through the media types registrations themselves one can determine if they represent RTP payload formats. Please note that some are both file formats and RTP payload formats. Thus, I would request that when updating the media type procedures and registry one should consider some clarifications to help identify media types that have RTP payload formats.

1. I would suggest that one add a column in the media types registry for each entry to indicate those that have RTP payload formats. 
2. Secondly there is the question if one like to convert the implicit indicator in the encoding information, that some but not all framed encodings are RTP, and rather have an explicit field in the registration template to say: Media Type has an RTP payload format.

comments.author: mnot
comments.body:
It's not scalable to add application-specific fields to the registry. Reasonable alternatives include:

1. using the 'general comments' field
2. creating a separate registry

comments.author: gloinul
mnot
comments.body:
Perhaps that should have been explicitly agreed to before closing the other registry.

Currently, there is _no_ other information that's limited to a specific subset of media types in the registry or in the registration template. Requiring that any new information captured be potentially applicable to all media types is a very reasonable and defensible position to take, with considerable precedence in the IETF. The fact that a particular community has got itself into an inconvenient position doesn't seem like a good reason to violate that principle.

comments.author: gloinul
alvestrand
comments.body:
To my mind, the "is RTP" information is not application specific, it's RTP specific. RTP formats is a field of use, not an application.

But - RTP doesn't really fit well with the other "encoding" descriptions like "binary", "8bit" or "7bit" since these presume the idea of a byte stream representation (aka "file").

So using "encoding: frames" (and making certain to specify that the "encoding" field is multivalued, and that the description of the possible values of the "encoding" field is right) seems like a good way to accomplish the purpose without bending things too much.

comments.author: ronieven
comments.body:
If you look at the registrations of video subtypes like h261 , h263, h263-1998, h264 you will see that the encoding field text is not consistence and restriction on usage is also used to indicate rtp support. H264 encoding, for example, just say rtp without even mentioning framed or binary. 
I also agree with Magnus that the problem with having two registration lists was the cause for failure making consistency between the two difficult to maintain and rfc9751 was the corr3ct decision. So some way to indicate clearly which subtypes are rtp is important

comments.author: alvestrand
comments.body:
On reading the text of -05, it seems to me that the description of the "framed" encoding type is adequate for the RTP formats, and can be easily extracted from the registration templates.
Let's take that as a proposed resolution for the text - and leave the issue of updating those as a maintenance issue.

comments.author: alvestrand
comments.body: Decision: Close with no action (the "framed" encoding in the template is adequate).

issues.title: Should the bucket format parameters from RFC 6381 be noted as something to consider?
issues.author: gloinul
issues.body:
https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/rfc6381/ defines parameters that are used to describe further properties of like codec capabilities of what is included in file formats that are so called bucket types, like the ISO based media file formats. 

Should there be a reference to these parameters and the consideration in the media type registry to ensure that this aspect is not forgotten. I can see that this could be either part of the relevant media top levels that commonly have these, or possibly under the parameter encoding section.

comments.author: gloinul
comments.body: I would also note that RFC 8088 do comment some other parameters that RTP payload format has used with the same definition over multiple media types used to register RTP payload format. I don't know if these needs to be noted or referenced that they exist to help registrants to include them if applicable.

comments.author: alvestrand
comments.body: Seems to fit under "advice on how to define parameters".

comments.author: mnot
comments.body: @gloinul could you suggest some text?

comments.author: gloinul
comments.body: @mnot proposal in #56.

comments.author: mnot
comments.body: Merged.

issues.title: Instructions for other SDOs on how to maintain registrations
issues.author: alvestrand
issues.body:
The procedures for IANA to check IETF work on updating specs is working reasonably well.
There are no corresponding procedures for other SDOs. They should be advised that they need to have one.

comments.author: mnot
comments.body: What should be said?

comments.author: alvestrand
comments.body:
We should ask other SDOs to say at which step they make registrations.
For IETF, it's "at IESG approval".
For W3C, it might be CR - or PR - or something else.
For 3GPP, I don't even know the names of the stages.

Unclear to me what "ask to say" means in this context.

comments.author: CxRes
comments.body: IMHO other SDOs should be asked to submit at what stage they make registrations requests to the DEs through IANA. DEs should be able to take a call if this is appropriate (e.g. the SDO is not rushing to register) and if not bring they might bring it up in issues or at a meeting.

comments.author: plehegar
comments.body:
fyi, W3C follows [registration process](https://www.w3.org/guide/editor/mediatypes.html#registration-process).  

cc @simoneonofri

comments.author: alvestrand
comments.body:
Things to consider:
- Notify the orgs on the "recognized standards orgs list" of 6838bis when it comes out
- Point at W3C procedures and ask "do you need something similar"
- Ask IANA what input they have on this point.

No change to this document contemplated.
Will put a note into the document's IANA considerations and let it disappear on publication. (Pete's suggestion)

issues.title: More detailed change procedures?
issues.author: alvestrand
issues.body:
Section 6.1 "Change procedures" is pretty short.
In particular, it doesn't say much about:
- Who can make changes (presumably "change controller")
- How one can make changes if change controller is unavailable or unresponsive
- When a change controller is supposed to make changes (for instance "if a listed contact point changes"?)

More text may be needed.

comments.author: mnot
comments.body:
> Who can make changes (presumably "change controller")

Text already says: "Once a media type has been published by the IANA, the change controller may request a change to its definition."

> How one can make changes if change controller is unavailable or unresponsive

This seems to be discussed in #9 (although arguably off-topic)

> When a change controller is supposed to make changes (for instance "if a listed contact point changes"?)

Currently, we put guardrails on what a change can request (e.g., no deletion) and require expert review for changes to assure sanity. Is that adequate?

comments.author: mnot
comments.body: I think this can be closed with no action, unless someone has a specific suggestion.

comments.author: 7439henry
comments.body: The RTP Payload Format for Haptics currently under development in AVTCORE is updating the Haptic media type defined in RFC 9695. We need an update since this document introduces optional parameters to enable extended functionality while maintaining backward compatibility. Before moving on to the next step (AD and IESG), we want to ensure that the current draft does not have any issues with the HMPG update.

comments.author: alvestrand
comments.body: As I understand what's been on the lists, the updates are to the subtypes defined in RFC 9695, not to the top-level type, and have listed SC29/WG7 as their change controller. I think updating of subtypes is described well enough in the current draft.

comments.author: alvestrand
comments.body:
I think we still have a somewhat underdocumented procedure for changing the change controller. The rest of the change procedures seem OK.

Moving to "LC blocking".

comments.author: mnot
comments.body:
As noted in #9, we currently have:

> The IESG may reassign responsibility for a media type. The most common case of this will be to enable changes to be made to types where the author of the registration has died, fallen out of contact, or is otherwise unable to make changes that are important to the community.

What kind of procedures are you envisioning? I suspect the circumstances are going to be diverse enough (in the nature of the party who was the change controller, the affected communities, and the nature of the cessation of contact) that a one-size-fits-all is going to be difficult.

comments.author: alvestrand
comments.body:
Might as well suggest specific text..... the most important points are:
1) Nothing happens if nobody wants to change anything (no busy-work)
2) The IESG acts on the DE's recommendation, not on the request directly (no DoS attacks on the IESG)

5.5 Old text:
"
The change controller of a media type may pass responsibility to another person or agency by informing the IANA; this can be done without discussion or review.

The IESG may reassign responsibility for a media type. The most common case of this will be to enable changes to be made to types where the author of the registration has died, fallen out of contact, or is otherwise unable to make changes that are important to the community."

New text:

"The change controller is responsible for sending the request to update the media type. Requests that are not authorized by the change controller will be rejected by the Designated Expert, except as described below.

If, in the opinion of the submitter, the change controller is uncontactable or unresponsive, a submitter can include a change of change controller in the updated registration template. In this case, the Designated Expert, after finding the change request otherwise reasonable and making reasonable effort to contact the old change controller, will recommend to the IESG that the change controller be changed; the IESG will make the final decision.

The most common case of this will be to enable changes to be made to types where the author of the registration has died, fallen out of contact, or is otherwise unable to make changes that are important to the community."

comments.author: mnot
comments.body:
I like this direction, but would prefer a slightly different angle:


When a change to a media type registration is requested, the Designated Expert will assure that the change controller approves the change. If the Designated Expert finds that the change controller is unresponsive or uncontactable for a reasonable period of time (no less than four weeks), and reasonable efforts have been made to contact them, they may recommend to the IESG that the change controller be updated. The IESG makes the final decision regarding updates to change controllers.


Here, we don't depend on someone in the community noticing and invoking the process, but they can still suggest this to the DE.

comments.author: alvestrand
comments.body:
Works for me - my thought was that I didn't want to make the DE responsible for knowing the list of change controllers and doing something when the status of someone on the list changes (death, company going away, SDO reorg...) - if there is no need to update the registration, nobody should need to care if the change controller is contactable.

I think the DE should be free to suggest such a change if that person thinks it's needed, which is better in the last version.

comments.author: alvestrand
comments.body: Decision: Adopt Mark's text, remove the parenthetical so as to not block the case of "we know no contact can be made".

issues.title: change media-types@iana.org to media-types@ietf.org
issues.author: anewton1998
issues.body:
6838 lists media-types@iana.org as the email to send registrations. However, this is just a forwarder to media-types@ietf.org. I suggest skipping the forwarder and changing the email address in 6838bis to media-types@ietf.org.

Also, it might be helpful to have an informative reference to the [list archive](https://mailarchive.ietf.org/arch/browse/media-types/).

comments.author: alvestrand
comments.body: We might want to ask IANABIS to formulate a general policy on IETF-related review list addresses, if we don't have one.

comments.author: alvestrand
comments.body: Sent off a quick note today. https://mailarchive.ietf.org/arch/msg/ianabis/IneNOsZleuL7pnJ-oeSOf09_4D4/

issues.title: Community format change controller
issues.author: mnot
issues.body:
Standards tree says:

> The "owner" of a media type registered in the standards tree is assumed to be the standards-related organization itself.

What should it be for community formats?

comments.author: alvestrand
comments.body:
Should we require the community to name a representative or representative organization?
I would assume that the normal case is change controller = registrant.

comments.author: mnot
comments.body:
That's sometimes difficult to pin down -- these communities are often amorphous.  How about something like:

> The "owner" of a media type registered using the community formats process can be an external organisation representing the relevant community. When one cannot be identified or contacted, the IESG should be listed as the owner of the registration.

comments.author: polx
comments.body:
As I remarked in another issue, having in this document more information about the way the IESG acts when it is a change-controller would be useful for people reading the document. Of course, it is possible to read about the IESG in other places but having one generic sentence here attracts confidence, I believe.

I would like to suggest, in the sentence above of @mnot , something like "the IESG should be listed as the owner of the registration which acts on it in a publicly visible forum".
WDYT?

comments.author: alvestrand
comments.body:
Rough consensus seems to be to designate the IESG when the DE does not see an obvious choice for a change controller.
Some feeling that asking the DE to make a judgment call without extensive guidance is not good.

Decision: Needs further discussion.

comments.author: mnot
comments.body: There's an argument here that the price you pay for avoiding the standards process but still getting access to the standards tree is that change control remains with a standards body (IESG) rather than the community that 'owns' the format. After all, if it's not able / organised enough to generate a standard for their format, it's reasonable to start from the position that they may not be organised enough to serve as a responsible change controller.

comments.author: polx
comments.body:
I fully agree that the IESG's automatic naming as a change controller is the "defacto choice" if there is no visible organized organization to name otherwise. 

To me this extra responsibility should be granted by having a sentence or two or the methods of change-management that IESG will apply. Simply stating public visibility would be probably enough. E.g. one could add the following: 

"When one cannot be identified or contacted, the IESG should be listed as the owner of the registration. The IESG will make any change visible in a public forum."

comments.author: alvestrand
comments.body:
I think we should say somewhere that "all changes to registrations follow the review process" (which includes IANA, at least, messaging the ietf-types@iana mailing list). I'm not sure we do that now, but it's nice and uniform to do so.

IESG shouldn't have a special "out" for that.

comments.author: polx
comments.body:
If this is done then it is fine for a reader that just drops by.
(I trust this is sufficiently done now but was worried about a reader that just reads it)

comments.author: alvestrand
comments.body:
Section 5.5 says that "the same procedure that would be appropriate for the original registration request is used to process a change request". I think that's adequate for ensuring that there's public review.

Section 4.1.1.1 doesn't mention considerations for defaulting the change controller yet - I think that would be a good change to make.

issues.title: Should coordination with previous registrar of +-suffixed types be required?
issues.author: bc-pi
issues.body:
It is extremely frustrating and belittling to feel that perfectly reasonable input that had support from other participants is subsequently being ignored. 

> This is text that I was explicitly objecting to at the previous in-person meeting and that I was under the impression that the author of this PR agreed as did at least one of the DEs.

_Originally posted by @bc-pi in https://github.com/ietf-wg-mediaman/6838bis/pull/14#discussion_r2000685271_

![Image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/df706dda-2b9e-454c-93fa-cca1639b5f4b)

comments.author: alvestrand
comments.body:
The chairs directed the editors to incorporate the current text from -suffixes without changes to the semantics.
We have noted that this is a point on which there is a need for further discussion before declaring consensus.
I didn't find the previous issue filed on the subject, so I changed the subject of this one, and will follow up.

comments.author: bc-pi
comments.body:
> The chairs directed the editors to incorporate the current text from -suffixes without changes to the semantics.

Was that before or after the WG meeting in Vancouver?

comments.author: mnot
comments.body:
Personally -- I don't object to having informative text about this in the spec -- i.e., setting the expectation that if you define a media type with a suffix, it shouldn't conflict with the 'base' type. However, using normative language and especially requiring that the DE reject such registrations is going too far. Give them the discretion to handle things appropriately. E.g.,

> A registration request for a media type that uses a suffix is expected to be coordinated with the change controller for any already registered media type with the same type and subtype names without the suffix -- in particular regarding semantics and data model.

comments.author: bc-pi
comments.body: Something like that that provides the DEs with discretion and doesn't put undue burden on them to police some notion of ownership would be, in my opinion, more reasonable.

comments.author: brentzundel
comments.body: I raised #41 as a starting point toward drafting language that can find consensus.

comments.author: bc-pi
comments.body: Is coordination with the change controller of the suffix expected as well? That seems equally relevant.

comments.author: alvestrand
comments.body:
I don't know if the change controller of the suffix is relevant.
Either the description of the suffix is sufficiently clear that it is obvious to the Designated Expert that the suffix is correctly used (or not), or we have a more critical problem.

The only case I can think of is where the registration is doing something that is inconsistent with the suffix definition, but the registrant argues that that's because the suffix definition is buggy. In that case, the suffix description needs updating first.

comments.author: brentzundel
comments.body:
I lean toward Harald's opinion here.

I believe it is reasonable to expect the designated experts to be able to determine that one of the ~20 structured suffixes is being used correctly. To expect them to know whether one of the >1600 application media types is being used used correctly doesn't seem reasonable to me. In those cases, having the submitter indicate that they've consulted with the change controller of the base type seems like it would be helpful to the DEs.

I'm also a bit concerned about the amount of times change controllers of suffixes would be consulted.
Most base types that are used with suffixes only have a few of them (if they have any), but suffixes are often used dozens of times. For example, the +jwt suffix is used 17 times, and the +json suffix is used over 150 times. If this guidance had been in place from the beginning, that would have been a lot of consultations.

That said, I have no problem adjusting the language in the PR if folks prefer it changed.

comments.author: bc-pi
comments.body: I was trying, rather unsuccessfully, for a bit of reductio ad absurdum on the very concept of suggesting consultation or requiring consent.

comments.author: alvestrand
comments.body:
Do not tie the hands of the DE.
Make language talk about what needs to be in the registration.

comments.author: mnot
comments.body: @alvestrand should the PR be merged?

comments.author: mnot
comments.body: PR merged; absent other discussion this should be closed.

comments.author: alvestrand
comments.body: Closing per discussion.

issues.title: Negative criteria repetitiveness
issues.author: mnot
issues.body:
Negative criteria says roughly the same thing four times:

* A top-level type is not a pointer into another registration space that offers duplicate registrations for existing media types. Example: a top-level type of 'oid', leading to types of the form oid/nnnnn, where nnn is an OID (Object Identifier) designating a specific media format,

* A top-level type MUST NOT be defined for the mapping of other protocol elements to media types. For example, while there may be some merit to a mapping from media types to URIs, e.g. in the context of RDF (Resource Description Framework), there is very limited merit in a reverse mapping, and even less merit in creating a top-level type for such a mapping. The same applies to other protocol elements such as file extensions or URI schemes. The recommended solution in case a mapping is needed is to choose a single type/subtype and put the additional information in an appropriately named parameter. As an example, information on a file extension '.dcat' can be encoded as 'application/octet-string; filename=foo.dcat'.

* Media types are not a general type system. A top-level type MUST NOT be defined if its main or only purpose is to map other type systems, e.g. in programming languages or ontologies.

* A new top-level type SHOULD NOT generate aliases for existing widely used types or subtypes.

There has to be a more efficient and friendly way to convey this; using bullet points implies that they're four different things, and they're not.

comments.author: alvestrand
comments.body: I believe this text was prompted by four different attempted registrations that were a Bad Idea..... we may want to wordsmith this to a single "don't ask for a top level type when it's not appropriate" and have the list of inappropriate registrations as examples.

issues.title: use of 2119 terms
issues.author: mnot
issues.body: The spec uses MUST/MAY/SHOULD throughout to indicate registration requirements, not interoperability requirements.

comments.author: alvestrand
comments.body:
In procedural documents like this, it seems that "interoperability" is the abillity for the parties to get their job done by conforming to procedure - "interoperability" between registrar and registry in this case.

I don't want to try to come up with an alternative terminology just because it isn't a computer protocol.

comments.author: mnot
comments.body: That's not my understanding of current IETF usage. We should clarify with the IESG.

comments.author: alvestrand
comments.body: It is consistent with 2119, which uses MUST to refer to its own requirements. What later guidance has been issued?

comments.author: mnot
comments.body:
Timely:
  https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/statement-iesg-statement-on-clarifying-the-use-of-bcp-14-key-words/

I read that as discouraging such use, but I can see an argument that it doesn't explicitly address this case.

comments.author: alvestrand
comments.body:
From the quoted guidance: "Notably, BCP 14 recommends these key words be used “sparingly” and mandates they not be used unless they are “actually required for interoperation or to limit behavior which has potential for causing harm.”"

If a registrant is required to do a particular thing in order to get a registration correctly processed, I see that as "required for interoperation" (with the registry) and has "potential for causing harm" (by delaying registration if the reviewers catch it, or by having inadequate or inappropriate registrations if the reviewers don't).

YMMV.

issues.title: Incorporate 'font' top-level type
issues.author: mnot
issues.body: ... from RFC 8081.

comments.author: svgeesus
comments.body: So would that contain all of RFC 8081, thus obsoleting it, or is it just a mention in a list of top level types?

comments.author: mnot
comments.body: We can't obsolete 8081 because it contains the subtype registrations, so I suspect it would be a short section and then a reference to 8081 for details.

comments.author: alvestrand
comments.body:
I don't think the registration procedure should attempt to be a complete listing of the registry (for obvious reasons - the registry is going to expand over time, the procedure can't reflect the future).

8081 is already referenced in [RFC 9694's history section](https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc9694.html#section-3). I don't see a good argument for treating it more specially than that. (PR #12 noted that it omitted the history section, and made a note about whether or not we should change that, but we don't have an open issue for that.)

comments.author: mnot
comments.body: Well, we could omit _all_ top-level type descriptions from this document...

comments.author: alvestrand
comments.body:
... and say "these are registered by 6838-no-bis? Works for me :-)
(unless we find that the old registrations are incomplete and need to be modified, in which case there needs to be an "updates to existing registrations" section ... the registration rules say that they need to be defined by a standards-track document, which is satisfied by 6838 or 6838bis as the WG wills it.)

comments.author: svgeesus
comments.body:
> 8081 is already referenced in [RFC 9694's history section](https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc9694.html#section-3). I don't see a good argument for treating it more specially than that.

I do.

The existing 8081 reference merely uses it as an _example_ on how to add a new top-level type.

As a currently-existing top-level type, though, `font/` (and `model/`) should be listed the same as the other top-level types

comments.author: mnot
comments.body: Hmm. I think we could remove the top-level type definitions _if_ there were a registry specifically for them, but there's not. Thoughts?

comments.author: alvestrand
comments.body: Well, https://www.iana.org/assignments/top-level-media-types/top-level-media-types.xhtml looks awfully like the registry created by 9694, so I guess we have one...

comments.author: mnot
comments.body: Aha! I didn't see that linked from the media types registry...

comments.author: mnot
comments.body: I think someone would need to go through and verify that none of the text regarding these in 6838 was unique.

comments.author: alvestrand
comments.body: Issue #29 created. With that, I think we can close this issue as "no action needed" (on the assumption that -bis won't have a list of top level types with descriptions in it).

issues.title: Applicability statements
issues.author: mnot
issues.body:
> It is expected that applicability statements for particular applications will be published from time to time in the IETF, recommending implementation of, and support for, media types that have proven particularly useful in those contexts.

Really?

comments.author: alvestrand
comments.body: Much has been expected of applicability statements, but little has been done about them....

comments.author: mnot
comments.body: I'm leaning towards just removing this.

issues.title: Review and maybe delete old top level type descriptions
issues.author: alvestrand
issues.body:
The old top level descriptions (text, application and so on) are referenced in the IANA registry at https://www.iana.org/assignments/top-level-media-types/top-level-media-types.xhtml as being defined in RFC 2026.

Their description is copied in the text of RFC 6838, and so far in 6838bis.

It would make for a shorter document if we could delete them and just say that 2026 is the normative reference for them, but before doing that, we need to verify that there are no changes to the description between 2026 and 6838 that we want to make normative.

comments.author: mnot
comments.body:
I had a fairly quick look through them all and am comfortable removing this text, which is largely duplicative.

However, we should make it more discoverable, by:
- Linking to the top-level types registry both in the draft and in the subtypes registry
- Specifying section numbers in the top-level types registry

comments.author: mnot
comments.body: PTAL at #36.

issues.title: Standards tree duplicates requirements and text
issues.author: mnot
issues.body:
The 'standards tree' section outlines requirements about publication and also specifies process for handling these registrations. Both of these are covered in other sections.

Should we:

1.  move all standards-tree requirements under the standards tree section (possibly removing duplicative text and requirements elsewhere), or
2. move these things out of the standards tree section into the requirements and process sections (possibly with appropriate references)?

I'm leaning towards (2).

issues.title: Vendor tree for community formats
issues.author: mnot
issues.body:
> Note that industry consortia as well as non-commercial entities that do not qualify as recognized standards-related organizations can register media types in the vendor tree.

Can this be removed now that we have the community formats process?

issues.title: Community formats and grandfathering
issues.author: mnot
issues.body: Does the community format process remove the need for the grandfathering text?

issues.title: Early Allocation
issues.author: mnot
issues.body:
Should we have an early allocation procedure? (make a placeholder, and get Designated Expert review)? (this applies also to other organizations) (Relevant: RFC 7120)

(From #8)

comments.author: brentzundel
comments.body: So, an early allocation procedure would enable specifications under development to set a placeholder for media types they intend to register once the specifications are finished?

comments.author: alvestrand
comments.body:
Seems that we had one. https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/rfc6838#section-5.2.1
Was it ever used? Do we need to change it?

comments.author: brentzundel
comments.body:
Oh yeah, I remember reading that once.
The existing text works for me, though I don't know if it has ever been used.

comments.author: mnot
comments.body: It seems like this can be closed with no action, then.

comments.author: CxRes
comments.body:
From what I recall of the Bangkok meeting, most IETF participants, including DEs were unaware of the early allocation procedure.  Since IETF processes are more rigorous for a regular registration, we had an instance where another SDO was able to claim a registration as discussed in #8. 

At a minimum, 6838bis should point to RFC7120 and an equivalent (or higher) bar be set for other SDOs to request an early allocation. Other SDOs should be asked to communicate their early allocation request requirements to the DEs through IANA. DEs can bring them up at a meeting/in issues if they feel the other SDOs request are inconsistent.

comments.author: alvestrand
comments.body:
Needs a pointer to RFC 7120. (and ref IANABIS)
May need to mention relation to other SDOs.

comments.author: mnot
comments.body: @alvestrand does the PR need more discussion or can it be merged?

comments.author: mnot
comments.body: Not having heard any further feedback, merging.

issues.title: Is there only a single media type reviewer and who appoints them?
issues.author: aamelnikov
issues.body:
In draft-ietf-mediaman-6838bis-05:

5.3.  Review and Approval

   With the exception of provisional standards-tree registrations,
   registrations submitted to the IANA will be first given to the media
   types reviewer, who is appointed by the IETF Applications Area
   Director(s).

Firstly, the text about media type reviewer was deleted elsewhere in the document.

Secondly, there are not Application Area Directors anymore, as the area is now ART.

comments.author: mnot
comments.body:
> Firstly, the text about media type reviewer was deleted elsewhere in the document.

Specifically?

> Secondly, there are not Application Area Directors anymore, as the area is now ART.

We could go with "Apps and Realtime", or we could just say "IESG" if we aren't sure there won't be another readjustment. Given that WIT also has a stake in this, I prefer the latter. Thoughts?

comments.author: alvestrand
comments.body: I would go with "the Area Director that the IESG has given responsibility for media type registrations", leaving the IESG to assign one. I'm sure there will be a new adjustment before another decade passes (but IESG is referenced so much that I doubt that IESG will be renamed or cease to exist as long as the IETF lives...)

comments.author: alvestrand
comments.body: Note - if we punt this to RFC 8126 section 5.3, as I suggested in #50, this issue goes away.

issues.title: Non IETF Stream registration in Standards Tree approval by IESG
issues.author: aamelnikov
issues.body:
I don't see a separate ticket explaining this change. My apologies if I missed it.

The new text in -05 says:

4.1.1.  Standards Tree

   Registrations in the standards tree are either:

   1.  approved directly by the IESG, or

and later:

   The first procedure is used for registrations from IETF Consensus
   documents.  See Section 2.2 for publication requirements.

I think there is one specific case that was lost in editing:

  Registrations published in non-IETF RFC streams are also allowed, but require IESG approval.

These are not necessarily "community formats", at least not at the time of registration.

comments.author: mnot
comments.body: @aamelnikov PTAL.

issues.title: Nit: Use https:// URLs consistently
issues.author: alvestrand
issues.body:
In section 1 and section 5.2, there are HTTP URLs. These should be https: URLs.
(both URLs sensibly redirect to the https: pages.)

issues.title: Nit: Remove standards-tree discussion from 2.2
issues.author: alvestrand
issues.body:
Section 2.2 specifies rules for how standards tree registrations are documented. This belongs in section 4.1.1 "Standards tree". In particular, 2.2 misses the community specification carve-out.

Sugestion: Delete the text in 2.2 prior to section 2.2.2.

comments.author: mnot
comments.body: Which text specifically are you referring to?

comments.author: alvestrand
comments.body:
"Media types registered in the standards tree by the IETF MUST be published as RFCs. Media types registered in the vendor and personal trees can be published as RFCs, but this is not required.

Standards-tree registrations for media types defined by other standards-related organizations MUST be described by a formal specification produced by that organization.

Other than IETF registrations in the standards tree, the registration of a media type does not imply endorsement, approval, or recommendation by the IANA or the IETF or even certification that the specification is adequate."

These paragraphs would actually improve section 4.1.1 (which doesn't mention publication requirements), but referring to the special rules for the standards tree before you define the registration trees seems out of sequence.

comments.author: mnot
comments.body: Moved. I had them under "Registration Requirements" because that's what they are, but don't feel strongly about it.

issues.author: alvestrand

issues.title: Nit: Replace "files" with "data" in 4.1.2 vendor tree
issues.author: alvestrand
issues.body:
Current text:

A registration may be placed in the vendor tree by anyone who needs to interchange files associated with some product or set of products.

Suggested text:

A registration may be placed in the vendor tree by anyone who needs to interchange data associated with some product or set of products.

Justification: A lot of the stuff that MIME types are used for never hits a file.

issues.title: Nit: Move section 4.2.4 ("Additional Structured Syntax Suffixes") into section 6, or delete
issues.author: alvestrand
issues.body:
This section seems to be about registration, not about what a structured syntax suffix is.

It would serve well as an introductory paragrahp to section 6.

issues.title: Media types reviewer could use more language
issues.author: alvestrand
issues.body:
Section 5.4 contains both the definition of the media types reviewer, the media types reviewer's role in the registration procedure, and the appeals procedure for decisions.

This could probably be broken into separate sections:

- A section defining the media types reviewer, what its role is and who appoints people to the role (perhaps a part of section 2). We may want to call out that this is a "designated expert" in the terminology of RFC 8126 section 4.5 (IANA considerations guidelines). That's also a good place to say that "there is one role, but the number of people filling it is at the discretion of the appointing body".
- A section on the role of the media types reviwer in the review process (section 5.4 is as good a place as anything)

The idea that decisions by the MTR can be appealed probably can go in either section.

comments.author: alvestrand
comments.body: Cross-linking #42 since the subject matter overlaps.

comments.author: alvestrand
comments.body:
In addition: At the moment, we have ~6 occurences of "Media types reviewer" (mostly in 5.3) and ~6 occurences of "Designated Expert". We might want to use one term.

RFC 8126 uses "designated expert" for the role and "expert review" for what the expert does, and seems to be consistent about it.

Also, [that document](https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/rfc8126#section-5.2.1) has language for appointing designated experts and appealing their decisions, which would allow us to avoid having to respecify that part.

issues.title: Should 6838bis use RFC8126 terminology for registration procedures?
issues.author: alvestrand
issues.body:
I think our procedure for the standards tree is "IETF review", for other-SDO registration it is "Specification Required", and for the vnd. and prs. faceted registries it is "Expert Review". But we don't refer to that terminology, so we don't inherit the requirements from that RFC.

Should we?

comments.author: mnot
comments.body: We do use that terminology and refer to that spec; see the trees section.

issues.title: 2119 language - need to restore some?
issues.author: alvestrand
issues.body:
This is raised to address concerns with https://github.com/ietf-wg-mediaman/6838bis/pull/34, which removed many occurences of 2119 language.

I think we should put a statement under "Conventions" saying that RFC 2119 language is  used to describe the requirements put on the registrant in the registration process. The other parties (reviewer, IANA, IESG) are governed by other types of agreements, and don't need to have their responsibilities codified using 2119 language.

In particular, notes from PR 34:

2.1.2 - "Copyright on the registration template MUST allow the IANA to copy it". While the whole paragraph seems a bit silly to me, this is a hard requirement on the registrant, and MUST is appropriate.

2.4 - "Media types can be defined to allow..." - suggest MAY is appropriate here.
"the names, values and meanings of any parameters are required to be fully specified...." - MUST is appropriate here,
lowercase "are required" is not clear enough.

4.1.2 - "when a third party register a type on behalf of someone else, both entities SHOULD be noted..." - this is a requirement on the registrant, where 2119 is appropriate.

5.1 - "Notice of a potential media type registration in the standards tree should be sent..." this is unclear about who is required to do the sending, I think the registrant is the right entity to send it, and it should be a MUST (was a SHOULD).

5.2.1 - "provisional registration ... can be submitted to IANA". Here, I think MUST is appropriate - because you get a registration if you submit this to IANA, you don't get a registration otherwise (for instance by posting on media-types) - and the requirement is on the registrant.

When reviewing for this language, I found a few places where it was unclear who does an action (too much passive voice). I'll raise a separate issue on that.

comments.author: mnot
comments.body: I'd like to get some clarity from the IESG on this -- as noted in #26, their statement _can_ be read to discourage use of 2119 terms for process concerns, but it's not crystal.

comments.author: alvestrand
comments.body: Tagging our AD @anewton1998 for further guidance in interpreting IESG guidance.

comments.author: mnot
comments.body:
Thanks.

@anewton1998 the context here is whether 2119 requirements are appropriate for process-related guidelines, or whether they should be limited to interoperability. IME depending on who you talk to in the IETF you can get either view (and we may be facing a vi vs emacs type situation here :)

comments.author: anewton1998
comments.body:
vi obsly!

I chatted briefly with the some other ADs, and the consensus was that 2119 language is acceptable for process docs. The changes suggest above by @alvestrand all seem reasonable to me.

My interpretation of that IESG statement (I think it was published 2 days before I got my dot) is that 2119 doesn't always need to be used where the normative instructions are obvious, such as "The JSON object always contains the following properties..." and that 2119 words are often used where they can't be normative: "Implementers MUST be aware of DDoS threats..." Neither seem to apply here.

WRT this doc, the part of the IESG statement that seems most relevant are the instructions about IANA.

comments.author: mnot
comments.body: Got it, thanks!

comments.author: aj-stein
comments.body: If we would like to propose insert of 2119 language for other process requirements for consideration by authors in the WG, would it be preferable to add them as a comment here or propose them in one or more PRs?

comments.author: mnot
comments.body:
This issue is about those 2119 requirements that were removed -- if you want to propose new ones, please open separate issues.

In general I think 2119 makes sense for the most important requirements - sprinkling MUSTs, MAYs and SHOULDs throughout the text just makes it harder to read.

issues.title: Meaning of an implied certification of a spec
issues.author: aj-stein
issues.body:
As I re-read the current draft, I found the ordering and usage of "certification" as an implied consequence of a registraton confusing. Does it have an essential meaning to this part of the document? Can we consider removing it?

https://github.com/ietf-wg-mediaman/6838bis/blob/e72821f1c15a29df353afe5a5abdd4f19e5d9ca6/draft-ietf-mediaman-6838bis.md?plain=1#L85

issues.title: Use of the qualifier "somewhat"
issues.author: aj-stein
issues.body: In the current draft, there are two uses of the qualifier somewhat. Although the usage is idiomatic, does it add essential meaning to either statement? To me, it does not further clarify the meaning in either cases, and I typically use this word to "walk back" a valid argument and defend it from criticism. Both places it is used are strong and I see no need for its use, if the authors use it like I do. Would we consider removing it?

issues.title: Do we need to define "readily available"?
issues.author: alvestrand
issues.body:
In the case of registering audio/SCIP and video/SCIP, there was a long debate about whether the specification was readily enough available.
In the end, "anyone can get a copy by requesting one from the listed address" was seen as "available enough".

Should we incorporate this into section 2.1.1 "Specification availability" somehow?

issues.title: Syntax in 2.3 - forbid multiple + signs?
issues.author: alvestrand
issues.body:
Section 2.3 says that the final + in a subtype name introduces a structured syntax specifier suffix.

Section 4.2 says that the structured syntax suffix is defined as all of the characters to the right of the left-most "+" sign, and cannot contain any more "+" signs.

Together, these rules outlaw more than one + sign, but the seeming conflict looks strange.
Should we replace "the final +" with "A + in a subtype name introduces... only one is allowed"?

issues.title: Incorporation of media type - passive voice?
issues.author: alvestrand
issues.body:
Currrent text in 2.8 is:

In the case of a registration in the standards tree, this additional information can be provided in the formal specification of the media type format. It is suggested that this be done by incorporating the IANA media type registration form into the specification itself.

It's not clear who is suggesting or who it is being suggested to. Also, this is only appropriate when the media type and the spec co-evolve; if registering an existing format as a media type, this can't happen.

Suggested replacement:

In the case of a specification where the registration is part of creating the specification, the IANA media type registration form can usefully be incorporated in the specification itself. This ensures that references between the registration form and the specification are consistent.

issues.title: IANA approval for "designation of the producer's name" is not specified
issues.author: alvestrand
issues.body:
If there's an existing process for registration of producers' names with IANA, we should point to it.

If there's not, we should either create it or say that "the Designated Expert will review whether the designation of the producer's name is appropriate" (ie leave IANA off the hook).

issues.title: Delete arguments for additional registration trees?
issues.author: alvestrand
issues.body:
4.1.5 says "It is explicitly assumed that these trees might be created for external registration and management by well-known permanent organizations; for example  scientific societies might register media types specific to the sciences they cover."

Given that this has never occured so far, I suggest that this text is speculative, and we should delete it.

issues.title: Coordination with previous registrants - passive voice?
issues.author: alvestrand
issues.body:
The current text is:

A registration request for a media type that uses an existing subtype or suffix is expected to be coordinated with the change controller for the already registered media type

It's not clear who's doing the expectation or who's doing the coordination. Suggested replacement text?

The Designated Expert will, when reviewing the registration request, check for documentation that the submitter has coordinated with the change controller for the already registered media type.

issues.title: Preliminary community review: should, SHOULD or MUST?
issues.author: alvestrand
issues.body:
Current text in 5.1:

Notice of a potential media type registration in the standards tree should be sent to the media-types@ietf.org mailing list for review. 

It doesn't say who sends it, and doesn't mandate such sending.
Suggesting alternate text:

The registrant SHOULD (or MUST) send a notice of a potential media tyep registration in the standards tree to the media-types@ietf.org mailing list for review.

issues.title: Effect of a provisional registration is not specified
issues.author: alvestrand
issues.body:
In section 5.2.1, we specify registration procedures for provisional registrations, but don't specify the effect of registering something there.

Suggested addition, something like:

The Designated Expert will check submissions for registration of names in the provisional registration list to verify that it has been adequately coordinated with the person or body referenced in the contact information of the provisional registration.

issues.title: Guidance on contact information (and possibly other fields)
issues.author: alvestrand
issues.body: We've had discussions about what should be in the contact information field (may be a WG or a mailing list) and in the change controller fields (IESG or appropriate other standards body for standards tree). Should this guidance be captured?

comments.author: alvestrand
comments.body: After discussion in Bangkok

```suggestion
* Top-level types can help humans with understanding and debugging. Therefore, evaluating how a new top-level type helps humans understand types may be crucial.
```

If the intention is to discourage oid/nnnnn, this text could be clearer.

For example: Do not attempt to register top levels which are pointers ....

```suggestion
* A top-level type MUST NOT be defined for the mapping of other protocol elements to media types. For example, while there may be some merit to a mapping from media types to URIs, e.g. in the context of RDF (Resource Description Framework), there is very limited merit in a reverse mapping, and even less merit in creating a top-level type for such a mapping. The same applies to other protocol elements such as file extensions or URI schemes. The recommended solution in case a mapping is needed is to choose a single type/subtype and put the additional information in an appropriately named parameter. As an example, information on a file extension '.dcat' can be encoded as 'application/octet-string; filename=foo.dcat'.
```

comments.author: gloinul
comments.body:
Thanks for the suggestions, simplified the last sentence also to make it more straightforward. 

@alvestrand do think anything should be done about the charset for text/* media types? If you do do you have a sentence?
The most well known "common" parameter is probably "charset" from the text/ top level type.

```suggestion
Some parameters are reused across multiple media type definitions to provide common functionality. For example, the 'Codecs' and 'Profiles' Parameters for "Bucket" Media Types {{!RFC6381}} identify media codecs used inside the container and their parameters. Another example is used with RTP payload formats: see {{!RFC4855}}, and {{!RFC8851}}.
```

Editorial nits above. I don't know what "indicate which media codecs and their complexity are represented inside the data object identified by the media type" means, though.
That should probably be replaced with "identify media codecs used inside the container and their parameters" - registration procedures shouldn't be concerned with what the parameters indicate.
Done.

```suggestion
Some parameters are reused across multiple media type definitions to provide common functionality. For example, the 'Codecs' and 'Profiles' Parameters for "Bucket" Media Types {{!RFC6381}} identify media codecs used inside the container and their parameters. RTP payload formats have several common parameters: see {{!RFC4855}}, and {{!RFC8851}}.
```
